data.title: A Bibliography
data.text:
Longfellow - A Bibliography

Below you will find a basic bibliography of print sources where readers can find more information on Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, his life, his works, and his influence. The majority of these sources can be found at the Maine Historical Society Research Library. Click here to search Minerva, Maine's online catalog. About half of our resources are cataloged online, while the remaining sources are in our onsite physical catalog. Another valuable resource is the Library's scrapbook collection, which consists of hundreds of newsclippings and similar resources on various local topics. For further information, contact the Maine Historical Society's Research Library at (207) 774-1822 x209.

Recent Longfellow-Related Publications

Alighieri, Dante. Inferno. Trans. Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. New York: The Modern Library, 2003.

A reprint of Longfellow's classic 1867 translation of Dante's Inferno, with a preface by Matthew Pearl and an introduction by Lino Pertile.

Henry Wadsworth Longfellow and His Portland Home, Portland, ME: Maine Historical Society, 2004.

A guide to the Wadsworth-Longfellow House featuring essays by Joyce Butler, former curator of the Maine Historical Society (MHS); Richard D'Abate, Executive Director of MHS; and Laura Sprague, restoration curator of the Wadsworth-Longfellow House.

Calhoun, Charles. Longfellow: A Rediscovered Life. Boston: Beacon Press, 2004.

The first new biography of Longfellow in almost fifty years.

Calhoun, Charles. "Longfellow's Portland" Creating Portland: History and Place in Northern New England Ed. Joe Conforti. Durham, NH: University of New Hampshire Press, 2005.

A compilation of scholarly essays on various aspects of Portland history and culture. Calhoun's essay focuses on Longfellow's relationship with the city of his youth.

Faragher, John Mack. A Great and Noble Scheme: The Tragic Story of the Expulsion of the French Acadians From Their American Homeland. New York and London: W.W. Norton & Company, 2005.

A comprehensive account of the Acadian expulsion by Yale University History Professor and prize-winning author Faragher.

Guth, Christine M.E. Longfellow's Tatoos. Seattle and London: University of Washington Press, 2004.

An examination of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's son Charlie and the time he spent in Japan.

Irmscher, Christoph. Longfellow Redux, University of Illinois Press, 2006.

A reexamination of Longfellow's work and the intense connection he had with his audience. Irmscher uses Longfellow's unpublished journals and letters from fans to great effect in this entertaining and important new look at America's favorite 19th century poet.

Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth. Evangeline: A Tale of Acadie. Coral Springs, FL: Lumina Press, 2004.

A special commemorative edition of Evangeline in honor of the 400th anniversary in 2004 of the first Acadian settlement, compiled and introduction and other supplementary material created by Francoise Paradis, Ed. D.

Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth. The Song of Hiawatha. Ill. Frederic Remington. Boston: David R. Godine, 2004.

An unabridged reprint of Longfellow's poem with the original Remington illustrations.

McClatchy, J.D., Ed. Longfellow: Poems and Other Writings. The Library of America, 2000.

A well-edited compilation of poems, translations, and prose by Longfellow. The volume also includes notes on the text and an extensive chronology of Longfellow's life and work.

Pearl, Matthew. The Dante Club New York: Random House, 2004.

A mystery novel centered on Longfellow's translation of Dante's Inferno. Longfellow appears as a central character.

Trachtenberg, Alan. Shades of Hiawatha: Staging Indians, Making Americans, 1880-1930. New York: Hill and Wang, 2004.

Trachtenberg, Professor Emeritus of English and American Studies at Yale University, examines the lives of Native Americans and of Asian and European immigrants at the turn of the 20th century America and the impact Hiawatha had on both groups.
